Garfield]] upon the [[Assassination of James A. Garfield|latter's assassination]]. At the outset, Arthur struggled to overcome a slightly negative reputation, which stemmed from his early career in politics as part of [[New York (state)|New York's]] [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[political machine]]. He succeeded by embracing the cause of [[United States federal civil service|civil service]] reform. His advocacy for, and subsequent enforcement of, the [[Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act]] was the centerpiece of his administration. Arthur was born in [[Fairfield, Vermont]], grew up in [[upstate New York]], and practiced law in New York City. He served as [[quartermaster general]] in the [[New York Army National Guard|New York Militia]] during the [[American Civil War]]. Following the war, he devoted more time to Republican politics and quickly rose in the political machine run by New York Senator [[Roscoe Conkling]]. Appointed by President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] to the lucrative and politically powerful post of [[Collector of the Port of New York]] in 1871, Arthur was an important supporter of Conkling and the [[Stalwart (politics)|Stalwart]] faction of the Republican Party. In 1878 the new president, [[Rutherford B. Hayes]], fired Arthur as part of a plan to reform the federal [[patronage system]] in New York. When Garfield won the Republican nomination for president in [[United States presidential election, 1880|1880]], Arthur, an eastern Stalwart, was nominated for [[Vice President of the United States|vice president]] to [[Ticket balance|balance the ticket]]. After just half a year as vice president, Arthur found himself in the [[White House|executive mansion]] due to the assassination of his predecessor. To the surprise of reformers, Arthur took up the cause of reform, though it had once led to his expulsion from office. He signed the Pendleton Act into law and strongly enforced its provisions. He gained praise for his veto of a [[Rivers and Harbors Act]] that would have appropriated federal funds in a manner he thought excessive. He presided over the [[History of the United States Navy#"New Navy"|rebirth]] of the [[United States Navy]], but was criticized for failing to alleviate the federal budget surplus, which had been accumulating since the end of the Civil War. Suffering from poor health, Arthur made only a limited effort to secure the Republican Party's nomination in [[United States presidential election, 1884|1884]]; he retired at the close of his term. Journalist [[Alexander McClure]] later wrote, "No man ever entered the Presidency so profoundly and widely distrusted as Chester Alan Arthur, and no one ever retired ... more generally respected, alike by political friend and foe."{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=420}} Although his failing health and political temperament combined to make his administration less active than a modern presidency, he earned praise among contemporaries for his solid performance in office. The ''New York World'' summed up Arthur's presidency at his death in 1886: "No duty was neglected in his administration, and no adventurous project alarmed the nation."{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=423}} [[Mark Twain]] wrote of him, "[I]t would be hard indeed to better President Arthur's administration."{{sfn|Feldman|p=95}} Over the 20th and 21st centuries, however, Arthur's reputation mostly faded among the public. ==Early life== ===Birth and family=== Chester Alan Arthur was born October 5, 1829, in [[Fairfield, Vermont]].{{efn|Some older sources list the date as October 5, 1830,{{sfn|Howe|p=5}} but biographer [[Thomas C. Reeves]] confirms that this is incorrect: Arthur claimed to be a year younger "out of simple vanity."}}{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=4|Howe||2p=4}} Arthur's mother, Malvina Stone, was born in [[Vermont]], the daughter of George Washington Stone and Judith Stevens. Malvina's family was primarily of English descent, and her grandfather, Uriah Stone, fought in the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolution]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=4|Howe||2p=4}} His father, William Arthur, was born in Dreen, [[Cullybackey]], [[County Antrim]], in what is now [[Northern Ireland]]; he graduated from college in [[Belfast]] and emigrated to Canada in 1819 or 1820. Arthur's mother met his father while William Arthur was teaching at a school in [[Dunham, Quebec]], just over the border from her native Vermont. The two married in Dunham on April 12, 1821, soon after meeting.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=4|Howe||2p=4}} After their first child, Regina, was born, the Arthurs moved to Vermont. They quickly moved from [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]] to [[Jericho, Vermont|Jericho]], and finally to [[Waterville, Vermont|Waterville]], as William received positions teaching at different schools.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=4|Howe||2p=4}} William Arthur also spent a brief time studying law. While still in Waterville, he departed from his legal studies and his [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] upbringing to join the [[Free Will Baptist]]s; he spent the rest of his life as a minister in that sect.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=4|Howe||2p=4}} William Arthur became an outspoken abolitionist, which often made him unpopular with members of his congregations and contributed to the family's frequent moves.{{sfnm|Howe||1p=7|Reeves|1975|2p=6}} In 1828, the family moved again, to Fairfield, where Chester Alan Arthur was born the following year; he was the fifth of nine children.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=5}}{{sfn|Howe|pp=5, 25, 28, 29}} He was named "Chester" after Chester Abell, the physician and family friend who assisted in his birth, and "Alan" for his paternal grandfather.{{efn|Arthur pronounced his middle name with the accent on the second syllable.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=5}}}} The family remained in Fairfield until 1832, when William Arthur's profession took them on the road again, to churches in several towns in Vermont and upstate New York. The family finally settled in the [[Schenectady, New York]] area.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=7–8}} The family's frequent moves later spawned accusations that Chester Arthur was not a native-born citizen of the United States. When Arthur was [[United States presidential election, 1880|nominated for vice president in 1880]], a New York attorney and political opponent, Arthur P. Hinman, initially speculated that Arthur was born in [[Ireland]] and did not come to the [[United States]] until he was fourteen years old. Had that been true, opponents might have argued that Arthur was constitutionally ineligible for the vice presidency under the [[United States Constitution]]'s [[natural-born-citizen clause]].{{sfn|Karabell|pp = 53–54}}{{efn|The [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] applies that clause, which specifically restricts presidential eligibility, to would-be vice presidents: "no person constitutionally ineligible to the office of President shall be eligible to that of Vice-President".}}{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp = 202–203}} When Hinman's original story did not take root, he spread a new rumor that Arthur was born in Canada. This claim, too, failed to gain credence.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp = 202–203}}{{efn|Among the facts that argue against Hinman's theories are the entries for Chester A. Arthur in several U.S. Censuses, which lists his birthplace as Vermont, and the entry of his birth in the Arthur family Bible, which also indicates Vermont as his birthplace. In addition, contemporary newspaper articles, including the 1871 stories about his appointment as Collector of the Port of New York, all indicate that he was born in Vermont, though some incorrectly give his birthplace as [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]]. Hinman failed to explain why Arthur would have fabricated these records and the biographical information he provided to newspapers to conceal a Canadian birth when the only thing being born in Canada might possibly affect was Arthur's eligibility for the presidency, which no one in the 1850s, 1860s or 1870s had any reason to think he would aspire to.}}{{sfn|Reeves|1970}} ===Education=== Arthur spent some of his childhood years living in the New York towns of [[York, New York|York]], [[Perry, New York|Perry]], [[Greenwich (town), New York|Greenwich]], [[Lansingburgh, New York|Lansingburgh]], [[Schenectady, New York|Schenectady]], and [[Hoosick, New York|Hoosick]].{{cite book |last=Ferris |first=Gary W. |date=1999 |title=Presidential Places: A Guide to the Historic Sites of U.S. Presidents |url=https://books.google.com/?id=AVvOyszUlpEC&pg=PA127 |location=Chicago, IL |publisher=R. R. Donnelly and Sons |page=127 |isbn=978-0-89587-176-3}} One of his first teachers said Arthur was a boy "frank and open in manners and genial in disposition."{{sfn|Howe|p=7}} During his time at school, he gained his first political inclinations and supported the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]]. He joined other young Whigs in support of [[Henry Clay]], even participating in a brawl against students who supported [[James K. Polk]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=7–8}} Arthur also supported the [[Fenian Brotherhood]], an [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] organization founded in America; he showed this support by wearing a green coat.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=9}} Arthur enrolled at [[Union College]], in Schenectady, New York, in 1845, where he studied the traditional [[Classical education movement|classical curriculum]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=7–8}} As a [[Senior (education)#Higher education|senior]], he was president of the debate society and was elected to [[Phi Beta Kappa]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p = 9}} During his winter breaks, Arthur served as a teacher at a school in [[Schaghticoke (town), New York|Schaghticoke]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=9}} After graduating, Arthur returned to Schaghticoke and became a full-time teacher, and soon began to pursue an education in the law.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=10}} While studying law, he continued teaching, moving closer to home by taking a job at a school in [[North Pownal, Vermont]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=10}} Coincidentally, future president James A. Garfield taught penmanship at the same school three years later, but the two did not cross paths during their teaching careers.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=11}} In 1852, Arthur moved again, to [[Cohoes, New York]], to become the principal of a school at which his sister, Malvina, was a teacher.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=11}} In 1853, after studying at [[State and National Law School]] in [[Ballston Spa, New York]], and then saving enough money to relocate, Arthur moved to New York City to [[Reading law|read law]] at the law office of [[Erastus D. Culver]], an abolitionist lawyer and family friend.{{sfn|Karabell|p=12}} When Arthur was admitted to the [[Bar (law)|bar]] in 1854, he joined Culver's firm, which was subsequently renamed Culver, Parker, and Arthur.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=14}} ==Early career== ===New York lawyer=== [[File:Chester A Arthur 1859.png|thumb|left|upright|alt=Black-and-white photograph of a young man with a mustache|Arthur as a young lawyer]] When Arthur joined the firm, Culver and New York attorney [[John Jay (lawyer)|John Jay]] (the grandson of the Founding Father of the [[John Jay|same name]]) were pursuing a ''[[habeas corpus]]'' action against Jonathan Lemmon, a Virginia slaveholder who was passing through New York with his eight slaves.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=14–15}} In ''[[Lemmon v. New York]]'', Culver argued that, as New York law did not permit slavery, any slave arriving in New York was automatically freed.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=14–15}} The argument was successful, and after several appeals was upheld by the [[New York Court of Appeals]] in 1860.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=14–15}} Campaign biographers would later give Arthur much of the credit for the victory; in fact his role was minor, although he was certainly an active participant in the case.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=16}} In another civil rights case in 1854, Arthur was the lead attorney representing [[Elizabeth Jennings Graham]] after she was denied a seat on a streetcar because she was black.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=16}} He won the case, and the verdict led to the [[desegregation]] of the New York City streetcar lines.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=16}} In 1856, Arthur courted [[Ellen Lewis Herndon Arthur|Ellen Herndon]], the daughter of [[William Lewis Herndon]], a Virginia naval officer.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=19–20}} The two were soon engaged to be married.{{sfn|Karabell|p=14}} Later that year, he started a new law partnership with a friend, Henry D. Gardiner, and traveled with him to Kansas to consider purchasing land and setting up a law practice there.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=16}} At that time, the state was the scene of a [[Bleeding Kansas|brutal struggle]] between pro-slavery and anti-slavery forces, and Arthur lined up firmly with the latter.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=17–18}} The rough frontier life did not agree with the genteel New Yorkers; after three or four months the two young lawyers returned to New York City, where Arthur comforted his fiancée after her father was lost at sea in the wreck of the [[SS Central America|SS ''Central America'']].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=17–18}} In 1859, they were married at [[Calvary Church (Manhattan)|Calvary Episcopal Church]] in Manhattan.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=21}} After his marriage, Arthur devoted his efforts to building his law practice, but also found time to engage in Republican party politics. In addition, he indulged his military interest by becoming [[Judge Advocate General's Corps, United States Army|Judge Advocate General]] for the Second Brigade of the New York Militia.{{sfn|Howe|pp=18–19}} ===Civil War=== [[File:Ellen Arthur.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Black-and-white photograph of a woman with dark hair|Arthur married [[Ellen Lewis Herndon Arthur|Ellen Herndon]] in 1859.]] In 1861, Arthur was appointed to the military staff of Governor [[Edwin D. Morgan]] as engineer-in-chief.{{sfn|Howe|pp=18–19}} The office was a patronage appointment of minor importance until the outbreak of the Civil War in April 1861, when New York and the other northern states were faced with raising and equipping armies of a size never before seen in American history.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=20–21|Reeves|1975|2pp=22–23}} Arthur was commissioned as a [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] and assigned to the state militia's [[quartermaster]] department.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=20–21|Reeves|1975|2pp=22–23}} He was so efficient at housing and outfitting the troops that poured into New York City that he was promoted to inspector general of the state militia in April 1862, and then to quartermaster general that July.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=24–25}} He had an opportunity to serve at the front when the [[9th New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment]] elected him [[colonel]] early in the war, but at Governor Morgan's request, he turned it down to remain at his post in New York.{{sfn|Howe|p=25}} He also turned down command of four New York City regiments organized as the Metropolitan Brigade, again at Morgan's request.{{sfn|Howe|p=25}} The closest Arthur came to the front was when he traveled south to inspect New York troops near [[Fredericksburg, Virginia|Fredericksburg]], Virginia, in May 1862, shortly after forces under Major General [[Irvin McDowell]] seized the town during the [[Peninsula Campaign]].{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=26–27|Reeves|1975|2pp=28–29}} That summer, he and other representatives of northern governors met with Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] in New York to coordinate the raising of additional troops, and spent the next few months enlisting New York's quota of 120,000 men.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=26–27|Reeves|1975|2pp=28–29}} Arthur received plaudits for his work, but his post was a political appointment, and he was relieved of his militia duties in January 1863 when Governor [[Horatio Seymour]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], took office.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=30}} When [[Reuben Fenton]] won the 1864 election for governor, Arthur requested reappointment; Fenton and Arthur were from different factions of the Republican Party, and Fenton had already committed to appointing another candidate, so Arthur did not return to military service.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=33}} On April 5, 1882, Arthur was elected to the District of Columbia Commandery of the [[Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States]] (MOLLUS) as a Third Class Companion, the honorary membership category for militia officers and civilians who made significant contributions to the war effort. He was assigned MOLLUS insignia number 2430.{{cite book |last=Aubin |first=J. Harris |date=1906 |title=Register of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States |url=https://books.google.com/?id=MoXlAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA20 |location=Boston, MA |publisher=Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States, Commandery of Massachusetts |page=20}} In addition, [[Grand Army of the Republic]] posts in [[Ogdensburg, Wisconsin]] and [[Medford, Oregon]] were named in his honor.{{cite book |last=Grand Army of the Republic, Department of Oregon |date=1919 |title=Journal of the Annual Encampment |url=https://books.google.com/?id=9bIPB0S4iegC&pg=PA83 |location=Salem, OR |publisher=State Publishing Department |page=83}}{{cite book |last= McCrory |first=Thomas J. |date=2005 |title=Grand Army of the Republic, Department of Wisconsin |url=https://books.google.com/?id=JeuBye82K0EC&pg=PA100 |location=Black Earth, WI |publisher=Trails Books |page=100 |isbn=1-931599-28-9}} Arthur returned to being a lawyer, and with the help of additional contacts made in the military, he and the firm of Arthur & Gardiner flourished.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=30–31|Reeves|1975|2pp=33–34}} Even as his professional life improved, however, Arthur and his wife experienced a personal tragedy as their only child, William, died suddenly that year at the age of three.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=29–30|Reeves|1975|2pp=34–35}} The couple took their son's death hard, and when they had another son, Chester Alan Jr., in 1864, they lavished attention on him.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=35}} They also had a daughter, Ellen, in 1871. Both children survived to adulthood.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=84}} Arthur's political prospects improved along with his law practice when his patron, ex-Governor Morgan, was elected to the [[United States Senate]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=37}} He was hired by [[Thomas Murphy (Collector)|Thomas Murphy]], a Republican politician, but also a friend of [[William M. Tweed]], the boss of the [[Tammany Hall]] Democratic organization. Murphy was also a [[Hatmaking|hatter]] who sold goods to the Union Army, and Arthur represented him in Washington. The two became associates within New York Republican party circles, eventually rising in the ranks of the conservative branch of the party dominated by [[Thurlow Weed]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=37}} In the [[United States presidential election, 1864|presidential election of 1864]], Arthur and Murphy raised funds from Republicans in New York and attended [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s [[Second inauguration of Abraham Lincoln|inauguration in 1865]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=38}} ==New York politician== ===Conkling's machine=== [[File:NYCustomHouseMerchantsExchange.jpg|thumb|250px|left|alt=A columned building with a domed roof|The [[New York Custom House]] (formerly the Merchants' Exchange building at [[55 Wall Street]]) was Arthur's office for seven years.]] The end of the Civil War meant new opportunities for the men in Morgan's Republican [[Political machine|machine]], including Arthur.{{sfn|Karabell|p=17}} Morgan leaned toward the conservative wing of the New York Republican party, as did the men who worked with him in the organization, including Weed, Seward (who continued in office under President [[Andrew Johnson]]), and [[Roscoe Conkling]] (an eloquent [[Utica, New York|Utica]] Congressman and rising star in the party).{{sfn|Karabell|p=17}} Arthur rarely articulated his own political ideas during his time as a part of the machine; as was common at the time, loyalty and hard work on the machine's behalf was more important than actual political positions.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=39|Howe||2p=37}} At the time, U.S. Custom Houses were managed by political appointees who served as Collector, Naval Officer and Surveyor. In 1866, Arthur unsuccessfully attempted to secure the position of Naval Officer at the [[New York Custom House]], a lucrative job subordinate only to the Collector.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=40–41}} He continued his law practice (now a solo practice after Gardiner's death) and his role in politics, becoming a member of the prestigious [[Century Association|Century Club]] in 1867.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=40–41}} Conkling, [[United States Senate election in New York, 1867|elected in 1867]] to the United States Senate, noticed Arthur and facilitated his rise in the party, and Arthur became chairman of the New York City Republican executive committee in 1868.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=42–45}} His ascent in the party hierarchy kept him busy most nights, and his wife resented his continual absence from the family home on party business.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=71–73}} Conkling succeeded to leadership of the conservative wing of New York's Republicans by 1868 as Morgan concentrated more time and effort on national politics, including serving as chairman of the [[Republican National Committee]]. The Conkling machine was solidly behind General Ulysses S. Grant's candidacy for president, and Arthur raised funds for Grant's election in 1868.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=48}} The opposing Democratic machine in New York City, known as [[Tammany Hall]], worked for Grant's opponent, former New York Governor Horatio Seymour; while Grant was victorious in the national vote, Seymour narrowly carried the state of New York.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=48}} Arthur began to devote more of his time to politics and less to law, and in 1869 he became counsel to the New York City tax commission, appointed when Republicans controlled the state legislature. He remained at the job until 1870 at a salary of $10,000 a year.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=49–50|Howe||2p=42}}{{efn|$10,000 in 1870 is equal to ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|10000|1870}}}} in present terms.{{Inflation-fn|US}}}} Arthur resigned after Democrats controlled by [[William M. Tweed]] of [[Tammany Hall]] won a legislative majority, which meant they could name their own appointee.{{sfn|Howe|p=42}} In 1871 Grant offered to name Arthur as [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue]], replacing [[Alfred Pleasonton]]; Arthur declined the appointment.{{cite news |title=Afternoon Dispatches: Pleasanton |work=The Tribune |location=Lawrence, KS |date=July 9, 1871 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/61286331/ |page=2 |subscription=yes}} Shortly thereafter, President Grant gave Conkling control over New York patronage, including the Customs House at the Port of New York. Having become friendly with Murphy over their shared love of horses during summer vacations on the [[Jersey Shore]], Grant appointed him to the Collector's position.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=51–53|Howe||2pp=44–45}} Murphy's reputation as a war profiteer and his association with Tammany Hall made him unacceptable to many of his own party, but Conkling convinced the Senate to confirm him.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=51–53|Howe||2pp=44–45}} The Collector was responsible for hiring hundreds of workers to collect the tariffs due at the United States' busiest port. Typically, these jobs were dispensed to adherents of the political machine responsible for appointing the Collector. Employees were required to make political contributions (known as "assessments") back to the machine, which made the job a highly coveted political plum.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=61–67|Schwartz||2p=182}} Murphy's unpopularity only increased as he replaced workers loyal to Senator [[Reuben Fenton]]'s faction of the Republican party with those loyal to Conkling's.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=57–58}} Eventually, the pressure to replace Murphy grew too great, and Grant asked for his resignation in 1871.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=57–58}} Grant offered the position to [[John Augustus Griswold]] and [[William Orton (businessman)|William Orton]], each of whom declined and recommended Arthur.{{sfn|Doyle & Swaney|p=188}} Grant then nominated Arthur, with the ''New York Times'' commenting, "his name very seldom rises to the surface of metropolitan life and yet moving like a mighty undercurrent this man during the last 10 years has done more to mold the course of the Republican Party in this state than any other one man in the country."{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=60|Howe||2pp=46–47}} The Senate confirmed Arthur's appointment; as Collector he controlled nearly a thousand jobs and received compensation as great as any federal officeholder.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=61–67|Schwartz||2p=182}} Arthur's salary was initially $6,500, but senior customs employees were compensated additionally by the "moiety" system, which awarded them a percentage of the cargoes seized and fines levied on importers who attempted to evade the tariff.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=59, 63, 85–86}} In total, his income came to more than $50,000—more than the president's salary, and more than enough for him to enjoy fashionable clothes and a lavish lifestyle.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=59, 63, 85–86}}{{efn|$50,000 in 1871 is equal to ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|50000|1871}}}} in present terms.{{Inflation-fn|US}}}} Among those who dealt with the Custom House, Arthur was one of the era's more popular collectors.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=68}} He got along with his subordinates and, since Murphy had already filled the staff with Conkling's adherents, he had few occasions to fire anyone.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=69–70}} He was also popular within the Republican party as he efficiently collected campaign assessments from the staff and placed party leaders' friends in jobs as positions became available.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=71–73}} Arthur had a better reputation than Murphy, but reformers still criticized the patronage structure and the moiety system as corrupt.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=61–67|Schwartz||2p=182}} A rising tide of reform within the party caused Arthur to rename the financial extractions from employees as "voluntary contributions" in 1872, but the concept remained, and the party reaped the benefit of controlling government jobs.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=76–77}} In that year, reform-minded Republicans formed the [[Liberal Republican Party (United States)|Liberal Republican]] party and voted against Grant, but he was [[United States presidential election, 1872|re-elected]] in spite of their opposition.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=78–79}} Nevertheless, the movement for civil service reform continued to chip away at Conkling's patronage machine; in 1874 Custom House employees were found to have improperly assessed fines against an importing company as a way to increase their own incomes, and Congress reacted, repealing the moiety system and putting the staff, including Arthur, on regular salaries.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=79–84|Howe||2p=49}} As a result, his income dropped to $12,000 a year—more than his nominal boss, the [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]], but far less than what Arthur had previously received.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=79–84|Howe||2p=49}} ===Clash with Hayes=== [[File:Arthur NYcustoms house cartoon.jpg|250px|thumb|alt=Cartoon of a man kicking another man into the street|A cartoon depicting President [[Rutherford B. Hayes]] kicking Arthur out of the New York Custom House]] Arthur's four-year term as Collector expired on December 10, 1875, and Conkling, then among the most powerful politicians in Washington, arranged his protégé's reappointment by President Grant.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=87–89}} By 1876, Conkling was considering a run for the presidency himself, but the selection of reformer Rutherford B. Hayes by the [[1876 Republican National Convention]] preempted the machine boss.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=95–96|Karabell||2pp=26–27}} Arthur and the machine gathered campaign funds with their usual zeal, but Conkling limited his own campaign activities to a few speeches.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=100–105}} Hayes's opponent, New York Governor [[Samuel J. Tilden]], carried New York and won the popular vote nationwide, but after the resolution of several months of [[Electoral Commission (United States)|disputes over twenty electoral votes]] (from the states of Florida, Louisiana, Oregon, and South Carolina), he lost the presidency.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=106–107}} Hayes entered office with a pledge to reform the patronage system; in 1877, he and Treasury Secretary [[John Sherman]] made Conkling's machine the primary target.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=100–105}} Sherman ordered a commission led by John Jay to investigate the New York Custom House.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|pp=318–319}} Jay, with whom Arthur had collaborated in the ''Lemmon'' case two decades earlier, suggested that the Custom House was overstaffed with political appointments, and that 20% of the employees were expendable.{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1pp=322–325|Reeves|1975|2pp=118–119|Howe||3pp=68–69}} Sherman was less enthusiastic about the reforms than Hayes and Jay, but he approved the commission's report and ordered Arthur to make the personnel reductions.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=119–120}} Arthur appointed a committee of Custom House workers to determine where the cuts were to be made and, after a written protest, carried them out.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=121–122}} Notwithstanding his cooperation, the Jay Commission issued a second report critical of Arthur and other Custom House employees, and subsequent reports urging a complete reorganization.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=121–122}} Hayes further struck at the heart of the [[spoils system]] by issuing an [[executive order]] that forbade assessments and barred federal office holders from "tak[ing] part in the management of political organizations, caucuses, conventions, or election campaigns".{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1pp=322–325|Reeves|1975|2p=121}} Arthur and his subordinates, Naval Officer [[Alonzo B. Cornell]] and Surveyor [[George H. Sharpe]], refused to obey the president's order; Sherman encouraged Arthur to resign, offering him appointment by Hayes to the [[United States Ambassador to France|consulship in Paris]] in exchange, but Arthur refused.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=121–123}} In September 1877, Hayes demanded the three men's resignations, which they refused to give.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=123}} Hayes then submitted the appointment of [[Theodore Roosevelt, Sr.]], [[L. Bradford Prince]], and [[Edwin Atkins Merritt|Edwin Merritt]] (all supporters of Conkling's rival [[William M. Evarts]]) to the Senate for confirmation as their replacements.{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1p=352|Reeves|1975|2pp=125–126}} The Senate's Commerce Committee, chaired by Conkling, unanimously rejected all the nominees; the full Senate rejected Roosevelt and Prince by a vote of 31–25, and confirmed Merritt only because Sharpe's term had expired.{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1pp=353–355|Reeves|1975|2pp=126–131}} Arthur's job was only spared until July 1878, when Hayes took advantage of a Congressional recess to fire him and Cornell, replacing them with the [[recess appointment]] of Merritt and [[Silas W. Burt]].{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1pp=370–371|Reeves|1975|2pp=136–137}}{{efn|[[Charles K. Graham]] filled Merritt's former position.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|p=370}}}} Hayes again offered Arthur the position of [[Consul (representative)|consul general]] in Paris as a [[Face (sociological concept)|face-saving]] consolation; Arthur again declined, as Hayes knew he probably would.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|p=354}} Conkling opposed the confirmation of Merritt and Burt when the Senate reconvened in February 1879, but Merritt was approved by a vote of 31–25, as was Burt by 31–19, giving Hayes his most significant civil service reform victory.{{sfnm|Hoogenboom||1pp=382–384|Reeves|1975|2pp=138–148}} Arthur immediately took advantage of the resulting free time to work for the election of [[Edward Cooper (mayor)|Edward Cooper]] as New York City's next mayor.{{sfn|Howe|p=85}} In September 1879 Arthur became Chairman of the [[New York Republican State Committee|New York State Republican Executive Committee]], a post in which he served until October 1881.{{cite news |title=Republican State Committee: Gen. Chester A. Arthur Elected Chairman -- Campaign Plans |work=The Sun |location=New York, NY |page=2 |date=September 12, 1879 |subscription=yes |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/78207539/ }}{{cite news |title=Organization of the Republican State Committee |work=The Post |location=Boston, MA |page=1 |date=October 12, 1881 |subscription=yes |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/72009166/}} In the state elections of 1879, he and Conkling worked to ensure that the Republican nominees for state offices would be men of Conkling's faction, who had become known as Stalwarts.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=153–155|Peskin||2p=704}} They were successful, but narrowly, as Cornell was nominated for governor by a vote of 234–216.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=153–155|Peskin||2p=704}} Arthur and Conkling campaigned vigorously for the Stalwart ticket and, owing partly to a splintering of the Democratic vote, were victorious.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=153–155|Howe||2pp=96–99}} Arthur and the machine had rebuked Hayes and their intra-party rivals, but Arthur had only a few days to enjoy his triumph when, on January 12, 1880, his wife died suddenly while he was in Albany organizing the political agenda for the coming year.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=158–159|Karabell||2pp=38–39}} Arthur felt devastated, and perhaps guilty, and never remarried.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=98–99|Karabell||2pp=38–39}} ==Election of 1880== {{main article|United States presidential election, 1880}} [[File:1880RepublicanPoster.png|thumb|250px|left|Garfield–Arthur campaign poster]] Conkling and his fellow Stalwarts, including Arthur, wished to follow up their 1879 success at the [[1880 Republican National Convention]] by securing the nomination for their ally, ex-President Grant.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=160–165}} Their opponents in the Republican party, known as [[Half-Breed (politics)|Half-Breeds]], concentrated their efforts on [[James G. Blaine]], a Senator from Maine who was more amenable to civil service reform.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=160–165}} Neither candidate commanded a majority of delegates and, deadlocked after thirty-six ballots, the convention turned to a [[dark horse]], James A. Garfield, an Ohio Congressman and Civil War General who was neither Stalwart nor Half-Breed.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=177–178|Howe||2pp=107–108|Karabell||3pp=39–40}} Garfield and his supporters knew they would face a difficult election without the support of the New York Stalwarts and decided to offer one of them the vice presidential nomination.{{sfnm|Karabell||1p=41|Reeves|1975|2p=178}} [[Levi P. Morton]], the first choice of Garfield's supporters, consulted with Conkling, who advised him to decline, which he did.{{sfn|Howe|pp=107–108}} They next approached Arthur, and Conkling advised him to also reject the nomination, believing the Republicans would lose.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=179–181}} Arthur thought otherwise and accepted. According to a purported eyewitness account by journalist William C. Hudson, Conkling and Arthur argued, with Arthur telling Conkling, "The office of the Vice-President is a greater honor than I ever dreamed of attaining."{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=179–181}}{{efn|Biographer George Howe takes this exchange at face value,{{sfn|Howe|p=109}} but later biographers suspect it may be apocryphal.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=179|Karabell||2pp=40–41}}}} Conkling eventually relented, and campaigned for the [[Ticket (election)|ticket]].{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=190–194}} As expected, the election was close. The Democratic nominee, General [[Winfield Scott Hancock]], was popular and, having avoided taking definitive positions on most issues of the day, he had not offended any pivotal constituencies.{{sfn|Jordan|pp=292–305}} As Republicans had done since the end of the Civil War, Garfield and Arthur initially focused their campaign on the "[[bloody shirt]]"—the idea that returning Democrats to office would undo the victory of the Civil War and reward [[Secession in the United States|secessionists]]. [[File:ElectoralCollege1880.svg|right|thumb|275px|1880 electoral vote results]] {{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=194–196|Jordan||2pp=294–295}} With the war fifteen years in the past and Union generals at the head of both tickets, the tactic was less effective than the Republicans hoped.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=194–196|Jordan||2pp=294–295}} Realizing this, they adjusted their approach to claim that Democrats would lower the country's [[tariff|protective tariff]], which would allow cheaper manufactured goods to be imported from Europe, and thereby put thousands out of work.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=196–197|Jordan||2pp=297–302}} This argument struck home in the swing states of New York and Indiana, where many were employed in manufacturing.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=196–197|Jordan||2pp=297–302}} Hancock did not help his own cause when, in an attempt to remain neutral on the tariff, he said that "[t]he tariff question is a local question", which only served to make him appear uninformed about an important issue.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=196|Jordan||2p=301}} Candidates for high office did not personally campaign in those days, but as state Republican chairman, Arthur played a part in the campaign in his usual fashion: overseeing the effort in New York and raising money.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=198–202}} The funds were crucial in the close election, and winning his home state of New York was critical.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=203–204}} The Republicans carried New York by 20,000 votes and, in an election with the largest turnout of qualified voters ever recorded—78.4%—they won the nationwide popular vote by just 7,018 votes.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=203–204}} The [[Electoral College (United States)|electoral college]] result was more decisive—214 to 155—and Garfield and Arthur were elected.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=203–204}} ==Vice presidency== {{main article|Inauguration of Chester A. Arthur}} [[File:CAArthur-oathofoffice.jpg|thumb|alt=A group of men, one with his hand raised|Arthur taking the oath of office as administered by Judge [[John R. Brady]] at [[Chester A. Arthur Home|Arthur's home]] in New York City, September 20, 1881]] After the election, Arthur worked in vain to persuade Garfield to fill certain positions with his fellow New York Stalwarts—especially that of the Secretary of the Treasury; the Stalwart machine received a further rebuke when Garfield appointed Blaine, Conkling's arch-enemy, as Secretary of State.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=205–207}} The running mates, never close, detached as Garfield continued to freeze out the Stalwarts from his patronage. Arthur's status in the administration diminished when, a month before inauguration day, he gave a speech before reporters suggesting the election in Indiana, a [[swing state]], had been won by Republicans through illegal machinations.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=213–216|Karabell||2pp=52–53}} Garfield ultimately appointed a Stalwart, [[Thomas Lemuel James]], to be Postmaster General, but the cabinet fight and Arthur's ill-considered speech left the President and Vice President clearly estranged when they took office on March 4, 1881.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=216–219|Karabell||2pp=54–56}} The Senate in the [[47th United States Congress]] was divided among 37 Republicans, 37 Democrats, one independent ([[David Davis (Supreme Court justice)|David Davis]]) who [[Congressional caucus|caucused]] with the Democrats, one [[Readjuster Party|Readjuster]] ([[William Mahone]]), and four vacancies.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=220–223}} Immediately, the Democrats attempted to organize the Senate, knowing that the vacancies would soon be filled by Republicans.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=220–223}} As vice president, Arthur cast [[List of tie-breaking votes cast by vice presidents of the United States|tie-breaking votes]] in favor of the Republicans when Mahone opted to join their caucus.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=220–223}} Even so, the Senate remained deadlocked for two months over Garfield's nominations because of Conkling's opposition to some of them.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=223–230}} Just before going into recess in May 1881, the situation became more complicated when Conkling and the other Senator from New York, [[Thomas C. Platt]], resigned in protest of Garfield's continuing opposition to their faction.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=230–233}} With the Senate in recess, Arthur had no duties in Washington and returned to New York City.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=233–237|Howe||2pp=147–149}} Once there, he traveled with Conkling to [[Albany, New York|Albany]], where the former Senator hoped for a quick re-election to the Senate, and with it, a defeat for the Garfield administration.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=233–237|Howe||2pp=147–149}}{{efn|Before the passage of the [[Seventeenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]], Senators were elected by state legislatures.}} The Republican majority in the state legislature was divided on the question, to Conkling and Platt's surprise, and an intense campaign in the state house ensued.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=233–237|Howe||2pp=147–149}}{{efn|Conkling and Pratt were ultimately denied re-election, being succeeded by [[Elbridge G. Lapham]] and [[Warner Miller]], respectively.}} While in Albany on July 2, Arthur learned that Garfield had been shot.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=233–237|Howe||2pp=147–149}} The assassin, [[Charles J. Guiteau]], was a deranged office-seeker who believed that Garfield's successor would appoint him to a patronage job. He proclaimed to onlookers: "I am a Stalwart, and Arthur will be President!"{{sfnm|Karabell||1p=59|Reeves|1975|2p=237}} Guiteau was found to be mentally unstable, and despite his claims to be a Stalwart supporter of Arthur, they had only a tenuous connection that dated from the 1880 campaign.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=238–241|Doenecke||2pp=53–54}} More troubling was the lack of legal guidance on [[United States presidential line of succession|presidential succession]]: as Garfield lingered near death, no one was sure who, if anyone, could exercise presidential authority.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=241–243|Howe||2pp=152–154}} Also, after Conkling's resignation, the Senate had adjourned without electing a ''[[President pro tempore of the United States Senate|president pro tempore]],'' who would normally follow Arthur in the succession.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=241–243|Howe||2pp=152–154}} Arthur was reluctant to be seen acting as president while Garfield lived, and for the next two months there was a void of authority in the executive office, with Garfield too weak to carry out his duties, and Arthur reluctant to assume them.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=244–248|Karabell||2pp=61–63}} Through the summer, Arthur refused to travel to Washington and was at his [[Chester A. Arthur Home|Lexington Avenue home]] when, on the night of September 19, he learned that Garfield had died.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=244–248|Karabell||2pp=61–63}} Judge [[John R. Brady]] of the [[New York Supreme Court]] administered the [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]] in Arthur's home at 2:15 a.m. on September 20. Later that day he took a train to Long Branch to pay his respects to Garfield and to leave a card of sympathy for his wife, afterwards returning to New York City. On the 21st, he returned to Long Branch to take part in Garfield's funeral, and then joined the funeral train to Washington.{{cite book|last1=McCabe|first1=James D.|title=Our Martyred President ... : The Life and Public Services of Gen. James A. Garfield|date=1881|publisher=National Publishing Company|page=764}} Before leaving New York, he ensured the presidential line of succession by preparing and mailing to the White House a proclamation calling for a Senate special session. This step ensured that the Senate had legal authority to convene immediately and choose a Senate president pro tempore, who would be able to assume the presidency if Arthur died. Once in Washington he destroyed the mailed proclamation and issued a formal call for a special session.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=247–248}} ==Presidency 1881–85== [[File:Arthur-cabinet.jpg|thumb|250px|left|alt=Drawing of a group of men looking at another man|''On the threshold of office, what have we to expect of him?''
In an 1881 ''[[Puck (magazine)|Puck]]'' cartoon, Arthur faces the [[James Garfield#Administration and Cabinet|cabinet]] after President Garfield was shot. ]] ===Taking office=== Arthur arrived in Washington, D.C. on September 21.{{cite news|title=The New Administration; President Arthur Formally Inaugurated|url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=980DE1D9103CEE3ABC4B51DFBF66838A699FDE|accessdate=14 January 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=22 September 1881}} On September 22 he re-took the oath of office, this time before Chief Justice [[Morrison R. Waite]]. Arthur took this step to ensure procedural compliance; there had been a lingering question about whether a state court judge (Brady) could administer a federal oath of office.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=53–54|Reeves|1975|2p=248}}{{efn|One presidential oath was administered by a state court judge, also in New York City by a New York State judge: [[Robert R. Livingston (chancellor)|Robert Livingston]], [[Chancellor of New York]], [[First inauguration of George Washington|administered the first presidential oath]] to [[George Washington]] at [[Federal Hall]] in 1789 (there were yet no federal judges). The only other presidential oath administered by someone other than a Federal justice or judge, [[First inauguration of Calvin Coolidge|the first swearing in]] of [[Calvin Coolidge]] in 1923 (by his father [[John Calvin Coolidge, Sr.]], a [[notary public]], in the family home), was also re-taken in Washington due to questions about the validity of the first oath.}} He initially took up residence at the home of Senator [[John P. Jones]], while White House remodeling he ordered was carried out, including the addition of an elaborate fifty-foot glass screen made by [[Louis Comfort Tiffany]], which remained in a White House corridor until it was dismantled in 1902.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=252–253, 268–269}} Arthur's sister, [[Mary Arthur McElroy]], served as White House hostess for her widowed brother;{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=252–253, 268–269}} Arthur became Washington's most eligible bachelor and his social life became the subject of rumors, though romantically, he remained singularly devoted to the memory of his late wife.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=275–276}} His son, Chester Jr., was then a freshman at [[Princeton University]] and his daughter, Nell, stayed in New York with a [[governess]] until 1882; when she arrived, Arthur shielded her from the intrusive press as much as he could.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=275–276}} Arthur quickly came into conflict with Garfield's cabinet, most of whom represented his opposition within the party. He asked the cabinet members to remain until December, when Congress would reconvene, but Treasury Secretary [[William Windom]] submitted his resignation in October to enter a Senate race in his home state of Minnesota.{{sfnm|Howe||1p=160|Reeves|1975|2p=254}} Arthur then selected [[Charles J. Folger]], his friend and fellow New York Stalwart as Windom's replacement.{{sfnm|Howe||1p=160|Reeves|1975|2p=254}}{{efn|Arthur first offered the post to Edwin D. Morgan, who had been his patron in New York; Morgan was confirmed by the Senate, but declined on the grounds of age. He died in 1883.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=254}}}} Attorney General [[Wayne MacVeagh]] was next to resign, believing that, as a reformer, he had no place in an Arthur cabinet.{{sfnm|Howe||1p=161|Reeves|1975|2pp=254–255}} Despite Arthur's personal appeal to remain, MacVeagh resigned in December 1881 and Arthur replaced him with [[Benjamin H. Brewster]], a Philadelphia lawyer and machine politician reputed to have reformist leanings.{{sfnm|Howe||1p=161|Reeves|1975|2pp=254–255}} Blaine, nemesis of the Stalwart faction, remained Secretary of State until Congress reconvened, then departed immediately.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=160–161|Reeves|1975|2pp=255–257}} Conkling expected Arthur to appoint him in Blaine's place, but the President chose [[Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen|Frederick T. Frelinghuysen]] of New Jersey, a Stalwart recommended by ex-President Grant.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=160–161|Reeves|1975|2pp=255–257}} Frelinghuysen advised Arthur not to fill any future vacancies with Stalwarts, but when Postmaster General James resigned in January 1882, Arthur selected [[Timothy O. Howe]], a Wisconsin Stalwart.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=162–163|Reeves|1975|2pp=257–258}} Navy Secretary [[William H. Hunt]] was next to resign, in April 1882, and Arthur attempted a more balanced approach by appointing [[William E. Chandler]] to the post, on Blaine's recommendation.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=162–163|Reeves|1975|2pp=257–258}} Finally, when Interior Secretary [[Samuel J. Kirkwood]] resigned that same month, Arthur appointed [[Henry M. Teller]], a Colorado Stalwart to the office.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=162–163|Reeves|1975|2pp=257–258}} Of the Cabinet members Arthur had inherited from Garfield, only Secretary of War [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] remained for the entirety of Arthur's term.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=162–163|Reeves|1975|2pp=257–258}} ===Civil service reform=== [[File:Chester A. Arthur by Ole Peter Hansen Balling.JPG|alt=Portrait of a man with a tremendous mustache|thumb|[[Ole Peter Hansen Balling]]'s 1881 portrait of Chester A. Arthur]] In the 1870s, a [[star route scandal|scandal]] was exposed, in which contractors for [[Star routes|star postal routes]] were greatly overpaid for their services with the connivance of government officials (including Second Assistant Postal Secretary [[Thomas J. Brady]] and former Senator [[Stephen Wallace Dorsey]]).{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=93–95|Reeves|1975|2pp=297–298}} Reformers feared Arthur, as a former supporter of the spoils system, would not commit to continuing the investigation into the scandal.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=93–95|Reeves|1975|2pp=297–298}} But Arthur's Attorney General, Brewster, did in fact continue the investigations begun by MacVeigh, and hired notable Democratic lawyers William W. Ker and [[Richard T. Merrick]] to strengthen the prosecution team and forestall the skeptics.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=299–300|Howe||2p=182}} Although Arthur had worked closely with Dorsey before his presidency, once in office he supported the investigation and forced the resignation of officials suspected in the scandal.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=299–300|Howe||2p=182}} An 1882 trial of the ringleaders resulted in convictions for two minor conspirators and a [[hung jury]] for the rest.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=301–302|Howe||2pp=185–189}} After a juror came forward with allegations that the defendants attempted to bribe him, the judge set aside the guilty verdicts and granted a new trial.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=301–302|Howe||2pp=185–189}} Before the second trial began, Arthur removed five federal office holders who were sympathetic with the defense, including a former Senator.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=303–305|Howe||2pp=189–193}} The second trial began in December 1882 and lasted until July 1883 and, again, did not result in a guilty verdict.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=303–305|Howe||2pp=189–193}} Failure to obtain a conviction tarnished the administration's image, but Arthur did succeed in putting a stop to the fraud.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=303–305|Howe||2pp=189–193}} Garfield's assassination by a deranged office seeker amplified the public demand for civil service reform.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=320–324|Doenecke||2pp=96–97|Theriault||3pp=52–53, 56}} Both Democratic and Republican leaders realized that they could attract the votes of reformers by turning against the spoils system and, by 1882, a bipartisan effort began in favor of reform.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=320–324|Doenecke||2pp=96–97|Theriault||3pp=52–53, 56}} In 1880, Democratic Senator [[George H. Pendleton]] of Ohio introduced legislation that required selection of civil servants based on merit as determined by an [[Civil service examination|examination]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=320–324|Doenecke||2pp=96–97|Theriault||3pp=52–53, 56}} In his first [[State of the Union|annual presidential address to Congress]] in 1881, Arthur requested civil service reform legislation and Pendleton again introduced his bill, but Congress did not pass it.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=320–324|Doenecke||2pp=96–97|Theriault||3pp=52–53, 56}} Republicans lost seats in the 1882 congressional elections, in which Democrats campaigned on the reform issue.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=99–100|Theriault||2pp=57–63}} As a result, the [[lame-duck session]] of Congress was more amenable to civil service reform; the Senate approved Pendleton's bill 38–5 and the House soon concurred by a vote of 155–47.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=324|Doenecke||2pp=101–102}} Arthur signed the [[Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act]] into law on January 16, 1883.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=324|Doenecke||2pp=101–102}} In just two years' time, an unrepentant Stalwart had become the president who ushered in long-awaited civil service reform.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=324|Doenecke||2pp=101–102}} At first, the act applied only to 10% of federal jobs and, without proper implementation by the president, it could have gone no further.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=325–327|Doenecke||2pp=102–104}} Even after he signed the act into law, its proponents doubted Arthur's commitment to reform.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=325–327|Doenecke||2pp=102–104}} To their surprise, he acted quickly to appoint the members of the [[United States Civil Service Commission|Civil Service Commission]] that the law created, naming reformers [[Dorman Bridgman Eaton]], [[John Milton Gregory]], and [[Leroy D. Thoman]] as commissioners.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=325–327|Doenecke||2pp=102–104}} The chief examiner, [[Silas W. Burt]], was a long-time reformer who had been Arthur's opponent when the two men worked at the New York Customs House.{{sfn|Howe|pp=209–210}} The commission issued its first rules in May 1883; by 1884, half of all postal officials and three-quarters of the [[United States Customs Service|Customs Service]] jobs were to be awarded by merit.{{sfn|Howe|pp=209–210}} That year, Arthur expressed satisfaction with the new system, praising its effectiveness "in securing competent and faithful public servants and in protecting the appointing officers of the Government from the pressure of personal importunity and from the labor of examining the claims and pretensions of rival candidates for public employment." ===Surplus and the tariff=== {{CSS image crop|Image = ARTHUR, Chester A-President (BEP engraved portrait).jpg |bSize = 310|cWidth = 230|cHeight = 270|oTop = 48|oLeft = 38|Location = left|Description = [[Bureau of Engraving and Printing|BEP]] engraved portrait of Arthur as president}} With high revenue held over from wartime taxes, the federal government had collected more than it spent since 1866; by 1882 the surplus reached $145 million.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=328–329|Doenecke||2p=168}} Opinions varied on how to [[Balanced budget|balance the budget]]; the Democrats wished to lower tariffs, in order to reduce revenues and the cost of imported goods, while Republicans believed that high tariffs ensured high wages in manufacturing and mining. They preferred the government spend more on [[internal improvements]] and reduce [[excise]] taxes.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=328–329|Doenecke||2p=168}} Arthur agreed with his party, and in 1882 called for the abolition of excise taxes on everything except liquor, as well as a simplification of the complex tariff structure.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=330–333|Doenecke||2pp=169–171}} In May of that year, Representative [[William D. Kelley]] of Pennsylvania introduced a bill to establish a tariff commission;{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=330–333|Doenecke||2pp=169–171}} the bill passed and Arthur signed it into law but appointed mostly [[Protectionism|protectionists]] to the committee. Republicans were pleased with the committee's make-up but were surprised when, in December 1882, they submitted a report to Congress calling for tariff cuts averaging between 20 and 25%. The commission's recommendations were ignored, however, as the [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Ways and Means Committee]], dominated by protectionists, provided a 10% reduction.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=330–333|Doenecke||2pp=169–171}} After conference with the Senate, [[Tariff of 1883|the bill that emerged]] only reduced tariffs by an average of 1.47%. The bill passed both houses narrowly on March 3, 1883, the last full day of the 47th Congress; Arthur signed the measure into law, with no effect on the surplus.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=334–335}} Congress attempted to balance the budget from the other side of the ledger, with increased spending on the 1882 [[Rivers and Harbors Act]] in the unprecedented amount of $19 million.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=280–282|Doenecke||2p=81}} While Arthur was not opposed to internal improvements, the scale of the bill disturbed him, as did its narrow focus on "particular localities," rather than projects that benefited a larger part of the nation.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=280–282|Doenecke||2p=81}} On August 1, 1882, Arthur vetoed the bill to widespread popular acclaim;{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=280–282|Doenecke||2p=81}} in his veto message, his principal objection was that it appropriated funds for purposes "not for the common defense or general welfare, and which do not promote commerce among the States."{{sfn|Reeves|1975|p=281}} Congress [[Veto override|overrode]] his veto the next day{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=280–282|Doenecke||2p=81}} and the new law reduced the surplus by $19 million. Republicans considered the law a success at the time, but later concluded that it contributed to their loss of seats in the elections of 1882.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=196–197|Reeves|1975|2pp=281–282|Karabell||3p=90}} ===Foreign affairs and immigration=== [[File:The only one barred out cph.3b48680.jpg|thumb|alt=A Chinese man sitting outside a locked gate|A political cartoon from 1882, criticizing [[Chinese exclusion]]]] During the [[James A. Garfield|Garfield administration]], Secretary of State James G. Blaine attempted to invigorate United States diplomacy in Latin America, urging reciprocal trade agreements and offering to mediate disputes among the Latin American nations.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=55–57|Reeves|1975|2pp=284–289}} Blaine, venturing a greater involvement in affairs south of the Rio Grande, proposed a Pan-American conference in 1882 to discuss trade and an end to the [[War of the Pacific]] being fought by [[Bolivia]], Chile, and [[Peru]].{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=55–57|Reeves|1975|2pp=284–289}} Blaine did not remain in office long enough to see the effort through, and when [[Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen|Frederick T. Frelinghuysen]] replaced him at the end of 1881, the conference efforts lapsed.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=129–132|Reeves|1975|2pp=289–293|Bastert||3pp=653–671}} Frelinghuysen also discontinued Blaine's peace efforts in the War of the Pacific, fearing that the United States might be drawn into the conflict.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=129–132|Reeves|1975|2pp=289–293|Bastert||3pp=653–671}} Arthur and Frelinghuysen continued Blaine's efforts to encourage trade among the nations of the Western Hemisphere; a treaty with Mexico providing for reciprocal tariff reductions was signed in 1882 and approved by the Senate in 1884.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=173–175|Reeves|1975|2pp=398–399, 409}} Legislation required to bring the treaty into force failed in the House, however, rendering it a [[wikt:dead letter|dead letter]].{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=173–175|Reeves|1975|2pp=398–399, 409}} Similar efforts at reciprocal trade treaties with [[Santo Domingo]] and [[Spanish West Indies|Spain's American colonies]] were defeated by February 1885, and an existing reciprocity treaty with the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] was allowed to lapse.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=175–178|Reeves|1975|2pp=398–399, 407–410}} The 47th Congress spent a great deal of time on immigration, and at times was in accord with Arthur.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=168–169|Doenecke||2p=81}} In July 1882 Congress easily passed a bill regulating steamships that carried immigrants to the United States.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=168–169|Doenecke||2p=81}} To their surprise, Arthur vetoed it and requested revisions, which they made and which Arthur then approved.{{sfnm|Howe||1pp=168–169|Doenecke||2p=81}} He also signed in August of that year the [[Immigration Act of 1882]], which levied a 50-cent tax on immigrants to the United States, and excluded from entry the [[mentally ill]], the [[intellectual disability|intellectually disabled]], criminals, or any other person potentially dependent upon public assistance.{{sfnm|Hutchinson||1p=162|Howe||2p=169}} A more contentious debate materialized over the status of Chinese immigrants; in January 1868, the Senate had ratified the [[Burlingame Treaty]] with China, allowing an unrestricted flow of Chinese into the country. As the economy soured after the [[Panic of 1873]], Chinese immigrants were blamed for depressing workmen's wages; in reaction Congress in 1879 attempted to abrogate the 1868 treaty by passing the Chinese Exclusion Act, but President Hayes vetoed it.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=277–278|Hoogenboom||2pp=387–389}} Three years later, after China had agreed to treaty revisions, Congress tried again to exclude Chinese immigrants; Senator [[John Franklin Miller (senator)|John F. Miller]] of California introduced another Chinese Exclusion Act that denied Chinese immigrants United States citizenship and banned their immigration for a twenty-year period.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=278–279|Doenecke||2pp=81–84}} The bill passed the Senate and House by overwhelming margins, but this as well was vetoed by Arthur, who concluded the 20-year ban to be a breach of the renegotiated treaty of 1880. That treaty allowed only a "reasonable" suspension of immigration. Eastern newspapers praised the veto, while it was condemned in the Western states. Congress was unable to override the veto, but passed a new bill reducing the immigration ban to ten years. Although he still objected to this denial of citizenship to Chinese immigrants, Arthur acceded to the compromise measure, signing the [[Chinese Exclusion Act]] into law on May 6, 1882.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=278–279|Doenecke||2pp=81–84}}{{efn|The portion of the law denying citizenship to Chinese-Americans was later found unconstitutional in ''[[United States v. Wong Kim Ark]]'' in 1898.}} ===Naval reform=== [[File:Squadron of Evolution (Hart).jpg|left|thumb|alt=Photograph of four warships|The "Squadron of Evolution" at anchor in 1889, after ''Yorktown'' had been added: ''Chicago'', ''Yorktown'', ''Boston'', ''Atlanta'']] In the years following the Civil War, [[United States Navy|American naval power]] declined precipitously, shrinking from nearly 700 vessels to just 52, most of which were obsolete.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1p=337|Doenecke||2p=145}} The nation's military focus over the fifteen years before Garfield and Arthur's election had been on the [[American Indian Wars|Indian wars]] in the West, rather than the high seas, but as the region was increasingly pacified, many in Congress grew concerned at the poor state of the Navy.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=338–341|Doenecke||2pp=145–147}} Garfield's Secretary of the Navy, [[William H. Hunt]], advocated reform of the Navy and his successor, [[William E. Chandler]], appointed an advisory board to prepare a report on modernization.{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=147–149}} Based on the suggestions in the report, Congress appropriated funds for the construction of three steel [[protected cruiser]]s (''[[USS Atlanta (1884)|Atlanta]]'', ''[[USS Boston (1884)|Boston]]'', and ''[[USS Chicago (1885)|Chicago]]'') and an armed dispatch-steamer (''[[USS Dolphin (PG-24)|Dolphin]]''), collectively known as the "ABCD Ships" or the "[[Squadron of Evolution]]".{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=342–343|Abbot||2pp=346–347}} Congress also approved funds to rebuild four [[monitor (warship)|monitors]] (''[[USS Puritan (BM-1)|Puritan]]'', ''[[USS Amphitrite (BM-2)|Amphitrite]]'', ''[[USS Monadnock (BM-3)|Monadnock]]'', and ''[[USS Terror (BM-4)|Terror]],'') which had lain uncompleted since 1877.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=342–343|Abbot||2pp=346–347}} The contracts to build the ABCD ships were all awarded to the low bidder, [[John Roach & Sons]] of [[Chester, Pennsylvania|Chester]], Pennsylvania,{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=343–345|Doenecke||2pp=149–151}} even though Roach once employed Secretary Chandler as a lobbyist.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=343–345|Doenecke||2pp=149–151}} Democrats turned against the "New Navy" projects and, when they won control of the [[48th United States Congress|48th Congress]], refused to appropriate funds for seven more steel warships.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=343–345|Doenecke||2pp=149–151}} Even without the additional ships, the state of the Navy improved when, after several construction delays, the last of the new ships entered service in 1889.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=349–350|Doenecke|2pp=152–153}} {{Clear}} ===Civil rights=== [[File:William Mahone.jpg|thumb|Readjuster Party leader [[William Mahone]] pressed civil rights in Virginia.]] Like his Republican predecessors, Arthur struggled with the question of how his party was to challenge the Democrats in [[Southern United States|the South]] and how, if at all, to protect the civil rights of black southerners.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=306–308|Doenecke||2pp=105–108}} Since the end of [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]], conservative white Democrats (or "[[Bourbon Democrat]]s") had regained power in the South, and the Republican party dwindled rapidly as their primary supporters in the region, blacks, [[Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era|were disenfranchised]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=306–308|Doenecke||2pp=105–108}} One crack in the [[Solid South|solidly Democratic South]] emerged with the growth of a new party, the [[Readjuster Party|Readjusters]], in Virginia.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=307–309|Ayers||2pp=46–47}} Having won an election in that state on a platform of more education funding (for black and white schools alike) and abolition of the [[Poll tax (United States)|poll tax]] and the [[pillory|whipping post]], many northern Republicans saw the Readjusters as a more viable ally in the South than the moribund southern Republican party.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=307–309|Ayers||2pp=46–47}} Arthur agreed, and directed the federal patronage in Virginia through the Readjusters rather than the Republicans.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=307–309|Ayers||2pp=46–47}} He followed the same pattern in other Southern states, forging coalitions with independents and [[Greenback Party]] members.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=307–309|Ayers||2pp=46–47}} Some black Republicans felt betrayed by the pragmatic gambit, but others (including [[Frederick Douglass]] and ex-Senator [[Blanche Bruce|Blanche K. Bruce]]) endorsed the administration's actions, as the Southern independents had more liberal racial policies than the Democrats.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=310–313}} Arthur's coalition policy was only successful in Virginia, however, and by 1885 the Readjuster movement began to collapse with the election of a Democratic president.{{sfn|Ayers|pp=47–48}} Other federal action on behalf of blacks was equally ineffective: when the Supreme Court struck down the [[Civil Rights Act of 1875]] in the ''[[Civil Rights Cases]]'' (1883), Arthur expressed his disagreement with the decision in a message to Congress, but was unable to persuade Congress to pass any new legislation in its place.{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=112–114}} Arthur did, however, effectively intervene to overturn a [[court-martial]] ruling against a black [[United States Military Academy|West Point]] cadet, [[Johnson Chesnut Whittaker|Johnson Whittaker]], after the [[Judge Advocate General of the United States Army|Judge Advocate General of the Army]], [[David G. Swaim]], found the prosecution's case against Whittaker to be illegal and based on racism.{{sfn|Marszalek|loc=''[[passim]]''}} The administration faced a different challenge in the West, where the [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS Church]] was under government pressure to stop the practice of [[polygamy]] in [[Utah Territory]].{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=84–85}} Garfield had believed polygamy was criminal behavior and was morally detrimental to family values, and Arthur's views were, for once, in line with his predecessor's.{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=84–85}} In 1882, he signed the [[Edmunds Act]] into law; the legislation made polygamy a federal crime, barring polygamists both from public office and the right to vote.{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=84–85}} ===Native American policy=== The Arthur administration was challenged by changing relations with western [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] tribes.{{sfn|Doenecke|pp=85–89}} The Indian Wars were winding down, and public sentiment was shifting toward more favorable treatment of Native Americans. Arthur urged Congress to increase funding for Indian education, which it did in 1884, although not to the extent he wished.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=89–92|Reeves|1975|2pp=362–363}} He also favored a move to the [[Allotment Era|allotment system]], under which individual Native Americans, rather than tribes, would own land. Arthur was unable to convince Congress to adopt the idea during his administration but, in 1887, the [[Dawes Act]] changed the law to favor such a system.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=89–92|Reeves|1975|2pp=362–363}} The allotment system was favored by liberal reformers at the time, but eventually proved detrimental to Native Americans as most of their land was resold at low prices to white [[Speculation|speculators]].{{sfnm|Doenecke||1p=91|Stuart||2pp=452–454}} During Arthur's presidency, settlers and cattle ranchers continued to encroach on Indian territory.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=89–90|Reeves|1975|2pp=362–363}} Arthur initially resisted their efforts, but after Secretary of the Interior [[Henry M. Teller]], an opponent of allotment, assured him that the lands were not protected, Arthur opened up the [[Crow Creek Reservation]] in the [[Dakota Territory]] to settlers by executive order in 1885.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=89–90|Reeves|1975|2pp=362–363}} Arthur's successor, [[Grover Cleveland]], finding that title belonged to the Indians, revoked Arthur's order a few months later.{{sfnm|Doenecke||1pp=89–90|Reeves|1975|2pp=362–363}} ===Health, travel, and 1884 election=== [[File:President Chester A. Arthur Yellowstone National Park Expedition 1883.jpg|250px|alt=A group of men seated in a forest|thumb|left|Arthur on an expedition in [[Yellowstone National Park]] along with [[Philip Sheridan]] and [[Robert Todd Lincoln]]]] Shortly after becoming president, Arthur was diagnosed with [[Bright's disease]], a [[kidney]] ailment now referred to as [[nephritis]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=317–318|Howe||2pp=243–244}} He attempted to keep his condition private, but by 1883 rumors of his illness began to circulate; he had become thinner and more aged in appearance, and struggled to keep the pace of the presidency.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=317–318|Howe||2pp=243–244}} To rejuvenate his health outside the confines of Washington, Arthur and some political friends traveled to Florida in April 1883.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=355–359|Howe||2pp=244–246}} The vacation had the opposite effect, and Arthur suffered from intense pain before returning to Washington.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=355–359|Howe||2pp=244–246}} Later that year, on the advice of Missouri Senator [[George Graham Vest]], he visited [[Yellowstone National Park]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=364–367|Howe||2pp=247–248}} Reporters accompanied the presidential party, helping to publicize the new [[History of the National Park Service|National Park system]].{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=364–367|Howe||2pp=247–248}} The Yellowstone trip was more beneficial to Arthur's health than his Florida excursion, and he returned to Washington refreshed after two months of travel.{{sfnm|Karabell||1pp=124–125|Reeves|1975|2pp=366–367}} As the [[United States presidential election, 1884|1884 presidential election]] approached, James G. Blaine was considered the favorite for the Republican nomination, but Arthur, too, contemplated a run for a full term as president.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=368–371|Howe||2pp=254–257}} In the months leading up to the [[1884 Republican National Convention]], however, Arthur began to realize that neither faction of the Republican party was prepared to give him their full support: the Half-Breeds were again solidly behind Blaine, while Stalwarts were undecided; some backed Arthur, with others considering Senator [[John A. Logan]] of Illinois.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=368–371|Howe||2pp=254–257}} Reform-minded Republicans, friendlier to Arthur after he endorsed civil service reform, were still not certain enough of his reform credentials to back him over Senator [[George F. Edmunds]] of Vermont, who had long favored their cause.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=368–371|Howe||2pp=254–257}} Business leaders supported him, as did Southern Republicans who owed their jobs to his control of the patronage, but by the time they began to rally around him, Arthur had decided against a serious campaign for the nomination.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=373–375|Doenecke||2pp=181–182}} He kept up a token effort, believing that to drop out would cast doubt on his actions in office and raise questions about his health, but by the time the convention began in June, his defeat was assured.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=373–375|Doenecke||2pp=181–182}} Blaine led on the first ballot, and by the fourth ballot he had a majority.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=380–381|Howe||2pp=264–265}} Arthur telegraphed his congratulations to Blaine and accepted his defeat with equanimity.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=380–381|Howe||2pp=264–265}} He played no role in the 1884 campaign, which Blaine would later blame for his loss that November to the Democratic nominee, Grover Cleveland.{{sfnm|Reeves|1975|1pp=387–389|Howe||2pp=265–266}} ===Administration and cabinet=== [[File:Daniel Huntington - Chester Alan Arthur - Google Art Project.jpg|alt=Portrait of a man in a fur coat|thumb|Official White House portrait of Chester A.
